This is the sort of the minimized version of what I use. Push and pop just allow me to not have to go to rust root to run commands :sweat_smile:

runRustStuff()
{
    pushd $RUST_PROJECT_REPO
    nice ./x.py fmt -j32
    nice ./x.py $@
    popd
}

buildRust()
{
    runRustStuff build -j50 -i --stage 1 $@
}

testRust()
{
    runRustStuff test -i --stage 1 $@
}

rustCheck()
{
    pushd $SG_RUST_PROJECT_REPO
    ./x.py check -j32
    popd
}
@Aman Arora I think you should be able to use the new src/tools/x binary instead of pushd and popd.
So IIUC it would be just nice x fmt -j32
And nice x $@

I'm late to the party but one of my fav zsh feature is global aliases

with

# Global aliases
alias -g G="| grep -i"
alias -g D="& disown"

you can do things like

$ cat ~/.zshrc G alias
# >> ALIASES
alias vim="nvim"
alias ls="exa --color=auto"
alias l="exa -lah"
...

$ zathura ~/me.pdf D

I have so many aliases :o n=nvim, g=git, l=exa -l, z to quickly jump directories. Many git aliases too: ci=commit, cia=commit --amend, ap=add -p, l=log, rbi=rebase --interactive, s=status, co=checkout, cob=checkout --branch , br=branch

Recently wrote a small script to help me with common x.py invocations too. Now I can write x test -k patterns instead of ./x.py test --bless src/test/ui --keep-stage 1 --test-args patterns. Also x perf runs a few selected benchmarks with rustc-perf and opens the browser to view the diff with master. Changed my life that one, now I just check perf after every commit instead of struggling with long post-hoc bisections

alias cup='for i in $(ls ~/.cargo/bin); do cargo install "$i"; done' :smiling_devil:
Does that work for cargo edit which installs cargo-add?
it will attempt to update everything in ~/.cargo/bin
the package names don't always match the binary -- e.g. cargo install ripgrep installs rg
anyway, there's a tool for this: https://crates.io/crates/cargo-update
alias cup='cargo-install-update install-update --all' :halo:
cargo install --list | rg '([\w-]+) v\S+:' -r '$1' | xargs cargo install
Needs ripgrep already installed and fails on things like pijul that currently has version 1.0.0-alpha.21
But works enough for me
yeah, that's the right way to do it
Same for pip3: pip3 list | rg '(\S+)\s+\d+.\d+.\d+' -r '$1' | xargs pip3 install --upgrade

function run_all_completions() {

    rustup completions zsh > $DIRCONFIG/zsh/_rustup
    pip3 completion --zsh > $DIRCONFIG/zsh/_pip3
}
